title: As a sole proprietorship why can't i claim protection under the FDCPA or the Rosenthal Act for a BofA, Wells or Chase loc?
question: Are there any protections for an individual doing business as "biz name" sole proprietor from unfair or unethical collection actions? I've been threatened with jail, called wet back, awaked at 5am, called on my job by collectors trying to collect a disputed line of credit for my detail business I started when my divorce was going on. The line of credit was in my name and Hector's Car Care Name. I am in San Jose, California and not a corporation or partnership.
answers: I agree with counsel - the FDCPA and RFDCPA protect consumers for "consumer debts" only - i.e. non business debts. I suggest that you seek a consumer protection attorney for an in person consult. This is usually done free of charge.

There is some case authority in which a court has found that a "business" credit card was actually a consumer debt and that the FDCPA was applicable. The cases are unique and involve additional issues. As far as the bad conduct of the collectors, you may have a good claim even if the FDCPA does not apply, as there may be a number of legal theories.

The FDCPA and California Rosenthal Act (RFDCPA) apply only to "consumer debt". Consumer debt is debt incurred primarily for "personal, family or household purposes." Neither statute applies to "business debt" - debt incurred primarily for a business purpose. Thus neither protects a debtor from debt collection harassment in the collection of the business debt. In my experience some pretty nasty stuff can be said in the collection of business debt. There are laws to protect debtors
from this sort of egregious behavior - a tort action for infliction of emotional distress, for example - but unlike the FDCPA and RFDCPA they do not contain an "attorney's fees" provision, whereby your attorneys fees are paid by the other side if you win. This is a significant impediment to finding an attorney.

In your case, having the loan in the name of your business suggests that your intend to use the credit for business purposes. Examine all the transactions on the account and make a determination whether the account was used primarily for "personal, family or household purposes." This is the true test., but it will be an uphill fight.

Under the FDCPA, a consumer debt is "any obligation or alleged obligation of a consumer to pay money arising out of a transaction in which the money, property, insurance or services which are the subject of the transaction are primarily for personal, family or household purposes, whether or not such obligation has been reduced to judgment." 15 U.S.C. 1692a (5)

If the debt you incurred was to support yourself or your household (as opposed to your business), then you are protected from this kind of harassment. Even if some part of the debt is business-related, the Act applies. There are consumer attorneys in your area who can help you.

Both FDCPA and Rosenthal Act apply. You should contact a consumer protection attorney in your area to discuss documenting these threats and harrassments to prepare a strong case against the perpetrator.
